Leonard L. Brown, an inventor in Greenville, S.C., obtained a patent this week on a method for keeping swimming pools clear of algae and bacteria without using chlorine.

The invention consists of mounting electrodes in the pipes of the pool's water filtration system. When current is applied, the electrodes react with the water and give off minute quantities of copper and tin. Although the metal quantities are too small to be detected, they create a hostile environment for microbe breeding.
Mr. Brown said there are two advantages to not using chlorine: Chlorine is irritating to the eyes, and it tends to evaporate and is believed to cause damage to the earth's ozone layer.
